Description: Lower body sherd of South Ionian pottery cup, probably a cup with everted rim; interior: wide black band on upper wall, reserved below; exterior: reserved band in handle zone, glazed below; inscription on interior.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2
Curator's comments: Schlotzhauer Identifies the sherd as possibly belonging to a Type 9A or Type 9B South Ionian cup with everted rim. Type 9A and Type 9B cups closely follow the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18) and Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type IX (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) and Villard’s Ionian Cup Type B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus, the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra, and at the site of Megara Hyblaea on Sicily. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. Unlike most cups of this type, the inscription is found on the interior surface of the bowl. Inscription on South Ionian cups with everted rims tend to be found on the exterior surface of the rim or upper body.
Bibliographic references: Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 54, no. 7)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.534) (Phase 3)
